name: Egilsstaðir - Capital of East Iceland
description: Egilsstaðir is the undisputed capital of East Iceland and the largest settlement in the Eastern Region, serving as the main center of services, transportation, and administration for this remote and beautiful part of the country. With a population of approximately 2,632 inhabitants as of 2024, this young town (founded in 1944) has grown into a vital hub that provides all essential services for travelers and residents alike, including supermarkets, hotels, restaurants, tour operators, an information center, souvenir shops, a regional hospital, a college, and Iceland's easternmost airport with regular domestic flights and increasing international connections. Located on the banks of the scenic Lagarfljót River in the wide Fljótsdalshérað valley, Egilsstaðir occupies a strategic position surrounded by some of East Iceland's most spectacular natural attractions, making it an ideal base for exploring the region. The town sits near two of Iceland's little-known gems: Hallormsstaðaskógur, Iceland's largest forest (a rarity in this largely treeless nation) where hiking trails wind through birch and conifer woodlands that feel almost magical in Icelandic context; and the mysterious Lagarfljót lake, Iceland's third-largest lake by volume, whose deep, dark waters are said to harbor the Lagarfljótsormurinn—a serpent-like monster similar to the Loch Ness Monster that has been "sighted" by locals for centuries and remains a beloved part of East Icelandic folklore.
